title: At least 1.85 million borrowers have never seen a rate rise
text:

Fri, Sep 25, 2015, 19:17 BST - UK Markets closed At least 1.85 million borrowers have never seen a rate rise By Nicole Blackmore | Telegraph – 41 minutes ago 0.00 
Borrowers fear they will struggle to keep up with mortgage payments when interest rates rise 
At least 1.85 million home owners have never experienced an interest rate rise and many fear they will not be able to meet their mortgage repayments when Bank Rate rises. 
Just over half of all borrowers believe they are likely to struggle or fall behind with their payments when the Bank of England pushes up rates, according to research published by the Building Societies Association. 
The trade body surveyed 2,000 borrowers and found that 10pc expect to experience real financial problems following a rate rise. 
A further 14pc said they will be able keep up with their repayments, but will struggle constantly, and a quarter expect to experience difficulty “from time to time”. 
When questioned about the impact on their lifestyle, 18pc of borrowers said they will have to cut back on essentials such as food or clothing in order to make their monthly repayments. 
A further 15pc said they will have to work more hours in order to keep on top of their mortgage commitments and 4pc said they will have to borrow money from other sources. 
Impact of a rate rise on borrowers' lifestyle 
Joanna Elson, of the Money Advice Trust, the charity that runs National Debtline, said after years of low rates, borrowers’ minds are beginning to focus on the prospect of higher interest rates and what this will mean for their finances. 
Mortgage calculator: The impact of rate rises on your mortgage 
“Nevertheless, many mortgage-payers are still in for a big financial shock when rates do start to climb and we remain concerned that many will fall into problem debt as a result,” he said. “We must not forget that renters, too, are likely to be affected as extra mortgage costs are passed on by landlords. 
“Households now have a window of opportunity to reassess their budgets, look again at their borrowing and think about how they will cope with higher interest rates. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is crucial they take advantage of this and prepare themselves now.” 
Bank Rate, which has remained at 0.5pc for more than six years, is not expected to rise until well into 2016 , according to markets. Some economists have predicted that the UK will not see a rate rise until as late as November next year.
